column7:
NOTES:
- GPIO pins are NOT conencted to the VeriComm module! Therefore, the in/out of GPIO pins cannot be directly read from or written to (HINT: You can implement logic in your design to propagte GPIO signals to pins accessible by VeriComm)
- When decoding & encoding VeriComm pins to read/write from the SMIMS engine, the index in the VeriComm column represents the number of bit shifts (<<, left shift)

IMPORTANT: For the output VeriComm, the index starts counting at 1, instead of 0 (input VeriComm counts starting at 0). Therefore, your mapping should have the following ranges (assuming you are maping the pin -> data index):
- input: 0~53
- output: 1~54
(These are stored in a 64bit uint (8bytes), that is split into 4 chuncks (2 bytes per chunk), giving us a total of 16 bits per chunk, which perfectly satisfies the width of the FIFO for the SMIMS engine.

Refer to VERICOMM_MAP.json & the python script (process_vericom_map.ipynb) for details.

Refer to Rabbit source code for more specific implementation details:
(ports/PinInfo.cpp, MainWindow.cpp:302, ButtonComponent.cpp:51, LEDComponent.cpp:49, FPGA/VLFDRunningHandler.cpp:18~105, etc.) There should be more, feel free to explore and discover for yourselves.
